subject: RE: [junit] Re: Why doesn't JUnit count asserts?

messageBody:
I don't have a strong opinion one way or another but I've seen a number of
appends that held up some number of tests as a metric of the effectiveness
of their unit testing. It would strike me that a more meaningful metric
would be the number of asserts, since that indicates how many conditions
were checked for correctness. So it is true that a unit test passes or it
doesn't and if it doesn't, you fix it and move on. However, if someone is
going to tout metrics, they should at least pick one that is as meaningful
as possible.

> Sorry to have noticed this thread so late. JUnit doesn't count
> asserts because they don't matter in unit testing--a test runs or it
> doesn't. If it doesn't, you don't have anything more important to do
> than fix it.
>
> Acceptance testing has different politics. There are styles of
> development/markets/customers where there *are* more important things
> to do than fix acceptance tests (I don't do this, but I understand
> the motivation). Then, degree of fuckedness is useful business input
> and worth tracking.
>
> Kent
> P.S. I apologize for the language. Not running a test correctly is
> bad.
